facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 893 of 1963

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 893 of 1963 Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 14, 1959 of the Assam High Court in Appeal from Original Order No. 21 of 1959.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 14, 1959 of the Assam High Court in Appeal from Original Order No. 21 of 1959

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 14, 1959 of the Assam High Court in Appeal from Original Order No. 21 of 1959. C. Setalvad, B. P. Maheshwari and M. S. Narasimhan, for the appellants.

facts.text: Appellants are the widow and son of Maliram Agarwala

anchor.surface_text: The appellants against whom the decree for ejectment is being executed are the widow and son of one Maliram Agarwala whose father Arjun Das had taken on lease the suit land from one Mohd. Soleman, predecessor-in-interest of the respondents.

facts.text: Arjun Das had taken on lease the suit land from Mohd. Soleman, predecessor-in-interest of the respondents

anchor.surface_text: whose father Arjun Das had taken on lease the suit land from one Mohd. Soleman, predecessor-in-interest of the respondents. The decree was passed as far back as November 28, 1950 in a title suit filed against the appellants and was later confirmed by the High Court.

facts.text: Decree for ejectment passed on November 28, 1950 in a title suit against the appellants

anchor.surface_text: The decree was passed as far back as November 28, 1950 in a title suit filed against the appellants and was later confirmed by the High Court. The present execution began on August 16, 1954 and was pending in the court of the Subordinate Judge, L.A.D., Gauhati when the Assam Non-Agricultural Urban Areas Tenancy Act, 1955 (Assam Act 12 of 1955) came into force from June 26, 1955.

facts.text: Decree confirmed by the High Court

anchor.surface_text: and was later confirmed by the High Court. The present execution began on August 16, 1954 and was pending in the court of the Subordinate Judge, L.A.D., Gauhati when the Assam Non-Agricultural Urban Areas Tenancy Act, 1955 (Assam Act 12 of 1955) came into force from June 26, 1955.

facts.text: Present execution began on August 16, 1954

anchor.surface_text: The present execution began on August 16, 1954 and was pending in the court of the Subordinate Judge, L.A.D., Gauhati when the Assam Non-Agricultural Urban Areas Tenancy Act, 1955 (Assam Act 12 of 1955) came into force from June 26, 1955.

facts.text: Execution pending in the court of the Subordinate Judge, L.A.D., Gauhati

anchor.surface_text: and was pending in the court of the Subordinate Judge, L.A.D., Gauhati when the Assam Non-Agricultural Urban Areas Tenancy Act, 1955 (Assam Act 12 of 1955) came into force from June 26, 1955. The appellants thereupon claimed the benefit of s. 5 of the Act which grants protection from eviction to tenants, under certain circumstances.

facts.text: Assam Non-Agricultural Urban Areas Tenancy Act, 1955 (Assam Act 12 of 1955) came into force from June 26, 1955

anchor.surface_text: Gauhati when the Assam Non-Agricultural Urban Areas Tenancy Act, 1955 (Assam Act 12 of 1955) came into force from June 26, 1955. The appellants thereupon claimed the benefit of s. 5 of the Act which grants protection from eviction to tenants, under certain circumstances.

facts.text: Appellants claimed the benefit of s. 5 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The appellants thereupon claimed the benefit of s. 5 of the Act which grants protection from eviction to tenants, under certain circumstances. The execution Court heard arguments and on November 12, 1957 held that the protection of s. 5 was available not only in pending suits and appeals but also in pending execution cases.

facts.text: Execution Court on November 12, 1957 held that s. 5 protection available in pending execution cases

anchor.surface_text: The execution Court heard arguments and on November 12, 1957 held that the protection of s. 5 was available not only in pending suits and appeals but also in pending execution cases. In reaching this conclusion the learned Judge followed a decision of the Assam High Court reported in Harsukh Saraogi Anr. v. Mashulal Khemani Anr. (1) and of the Calcutta High Court in Habiba Bibi and others v. Ram Ranjan Mullick and others (2) He accordingly fixed the case for evidence to find out if there existed facts necessary for the application of s. 5 of the Act.

facts.text: Execution Court followed Harsukh Saraogi Anr. v. Mashulal Khemani Anr. AIR 1957 Assam 22

anchor.surface_text: In reaching this conclusion the learned Judge followed a decision of the Assam High Court reported in Harsukh Saraogi Anr. v. Mashulal Khemani Anr. (1) and of the Calcutta High Court in Habiba Bibi and others v. Ram Ranjan Mullick and others (2)

facts.text: Execution Court fixed the case for evidence

anchor.surface_text: He accordingly fixed the case for evidence to find out if there existed facts necessary for the application of s. 5 of the Act. Subsequently, the Presiding Judge having changed, the point was reopened on June 6, 1959 by the successor Judge.

facts.text: Point reopened on June 6, 1959 by successor Judge

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, the Presiding Judge having changed, the point was reopened on June 6, 1959 by the successor Judge. That learned Judge following a later decision of the Assam High Court since reported in Suresh Chandra Datta v. Ashutosh Dutta and others (3) held that s. 5 (1) (a) was not applicable to execution proceedings and the pending execution must proceed according to law.

facts.text: Successor Judge held s. 5(1)(a) not applicable to execution proceedings following Suresh Chandra Datta v. Ashutosh Dutta AIR 1960 Assam 24

anchor.surface_text: That learned Judge following a later decision of the Assam High Court since reported in Suresh Chandra Datta v. Ashutosh Dutta and others (3) held that s. 5 (1) (a) was not applicable to execution proceedings and the pending execution must proceed according to law. The only question in this case is whether the provisions of s. 5 (1) (a) of the Tenancy Act apply to pending execution proceedings.

facts.text: High Court of Assam order dated August 14, 1959 rejecting summarily an appeal in execution case

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave against an order of the High Court of Assam dated August 14, 1959 rejecting summarily an appeal in an execution case. The appellants against whom the decree for ejectment is being executed are the widow and son of one Maliram Agarwala whose father Arjun Das had taken on lease the suit land from one Mohd. Soleman, predecessor-in-interest of the respondents.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by Hidaytullah J.

anchor.surface_text: Sen, and P. K. Ghosh, for the respondents. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Hidaytullah J. This is an appeal by special leave against an order of the High Court of Assam dated August 14, 1959 rejecting summarily an appeal in an execution case.

facts.text: Assam Non-Agricultural Urban Areas Tenancy Act, 1955 consists of 14 sections

anchor.surface_text: The Act was passed to regulate in certain respects the relationship between landlord and tenant in respect of non-agricultural A.I.R. 1957 Assam 22. (2) A.I.R. 1937 Cal 207. (3) A.I.R. 1960 Assam 24. land in urban areas of the State of Assam. It consists of 14 sections.

facts.text: Sylhet Non-Agricultural Urban Areas Tenancy Act, 1917 (Assam Act 10 of 1947) was repealed by s.14

anchor.surface_text: By s. 14, the Sylhet Non-Agricultural Urban Areas Tenancy Act, 1917, (Assam Act 10 of 1947) was repealed. The only question in this appeal is whether s. 5 (1) (a) of the Act, which we have reproduced above, applies to execution cases in respect of decrees for ejectment granted before the coming into force of the Tenancy Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that s. 5(1)(a) does not apply to execution proceedings for decrees granted before the Act

anchor.surface_text: The decision under appeal was, therefore, right.

arguments.claim: s. 5(3) applies peremptorily only to decrees for ejectment on ground of non-payment of rent, leaving other pre-Act decrees executable

anchor.surface_text: The third sub-section deals with decree of ejectment passed on the ground of numberpayment of rent. It affords a last chance to the tenant to retain the land of his tenancy by making such a decree unexecutable for a period of 30 days from its date so that the tenant may, if he cares, deposit the amount of the decree in the companyrt which will execute that decree. On the tenant so paying, the decree is recorded as satisfied. This sub-section must apply to all executions which companye within its terms because of the clear language numberdecree for ejectment shall be executed and the Court shall record the decree as satisfied. These are peremptory words and they do number admit of any exception.

arguments.claim: s. 5(2) recognizes that ejectment is possible in execution of a decree passed by a competent civil court

anchor.surface_text: We may number examine the second sub-section which also takes away some rights of landlords but leaves them free to execute decrees other than those on which the section places an embargo. That sub-section provides that numbertenant shall be ejected by his landlord from the land of his tenancy except in execution of a decree for ejectment passed by a companypetent civil companyrt.

arguments.claim: s. 5(1) limits the landlord's right to eject the tenant, not execution of existing ejectment decrees; non-obstante clause does not include already obtained decrees

anchor.surface_text: Certain matters appear on its face. Ihe sub-section does number speak of an ejectment decree, but of the right of the landlord to eject his tenant. It begins by stating numberwithstanding anything in any companytract or in any law for the time being in force but it does number include decrees for ejectment already obtained, in the number-obstante clause. Such decrees companyld have easily been named, to include them within the protective provisions, but they were number.

arguments.claim: s. 5(1)(b) operates on landlord rights enforced by suit, not on already determined rights in execution, as s. 6 refers only to suits for ejectment

anchor.surface_text: Taking b first if the tenant effects improvements on the land which he is number entitled to effect, the landlord may number eject him unless he pays reasonable companypensation. Who will assess the companypensation is laid down in s. 6 but that section specifically mentions a suit for ejectment and number execution proceeding. All this seems to suggest that s. 5 1 b is intended to operate on rights of the landlord which are being enforced by a suit but number on rights already enforced and determined.

arguments.claim: s. 5(1)(a) contemplates enforcement by suit and not execution proceedings, similar to s. 5(1)(b)

anchor.surface_text: Part a of s. 5 1 is companystructed on very similar lines and does number admit a different approach. It protects tenants of land from ejectment by the landlord in those cases in which the tenant entitled to build on the land under his companytract has actually built a permanent structure within five years from the date of his companytract, or has without such right built with the knowledge and acquiescence of the landlord. Such tenant may number be ejected except for number-payment of rent.

arguments.claim: The conclusion that s. 5 does not apply to execution of pre-Act decrees is supported by Suresh Chandra decision of Assam High Court

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the Assam High Court in Suresh Chandra v. Ashutosh Dutta 1 expressed the same companyclusion but on a slightly different reasoning.

arguments.claim: Prior Assam Acts (Sylhet NAUTA 1947 s.14, Assam UARCA 1946/1949 s.6(1)) explicitly included execution proceedings when intended; absence in 1955 Act is deliberate

anchor.surface_text: Section 14 of the Sylhet Non-Agricultural Urban Areas Tenancy Act, 1947 (Assam Act 10 of 1947) number repealed by the Act we are companysidering, provided in clear terms that proceedings in execution were included. ... Similarly, s. 6 1 of the Assam Urban Areas Rent Control Act 1949 (Assam Act 13 of 1949) and s. 6 1 of the Assam Urban Areas Rent Control Act, 1946 (Assam Act 3 of 1946) provided specially for execution proceedings.

arguments.claim: The Assam Legislature was aware of how to include execution proceedings if desired, having models in prior Acts, but deliberately departed in the 1955 Act

anchor.surface_text: These enactments, which are quite explicit, show that where the Assam Legislature wished it included execution proceedings within the protection. Being aware that if execution proceedings are to be included they need to be mentioned and having at hand the former sections as models, the departure appears to be deliberate. The language chosen places the right under an embargo but does number say that decrees already won would become unexecutable thus stating clearly that they were number to be affected.

holdings.text: The provisions of s. 5(1)(a) of the Tenancy Act do not apply to pending execution proceedings for decrees for ejectment granted before the coming into force of the Tenancy Act

anchor.surface_text: held that s. 5 (1) (a) was not applicable to execution proceedings and the pending execution must proceed according to law. The only question in this case is whether the provisions of s. 5 (1) (a) of the Tenancy Act apply to pending execution proceedings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of s.5(1)(a) and (b) shows it limits landlord's right to eject via suit, not execution of existing decrees; s.5(2) recognizes decree executions; s.6 limited to suits; prior Assam Acts explicitly included executions when intended, deliberate omission here

holdings.text: s. 5(1)(a) of the Act does not apply to execution cases in respect of decrees for ejectment granted before the coming into force of the Tenancy Act

anchor.surface_text: By s. 14, the Sylhet Non-Agricultural Urban Areas Tenancy Act, 1917, (Assam Act 10 of 1947) was repealed. The only question in this appeal is whether s. 5 (1) (a) of the Act, which we have reproduced above, applies to execution cases in respect of decrees for ejectment granted before the coming into force of the Tenancy Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirmation of lower courts after independent analysis confirming s.5 targets ongoing suits not pre-existing decrees; supported by legislative history of prior explicit inclusions

holdings.text: s.5(3) must apply to all executions which come within its terms; peremptory words admit no exception

anchor.surface_text: This sub-section must apply to all executions which come within its terms because of the clear language nodecree for ejectment shall be executed and the Court shall record the decree as satisfied. These are peremptory words and they do not admit of any exception.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clear textual language of s.5(3) mandates application to qualifying non-payment decrees without exception

holdings.text: s.5(2) recognizes that ejectment is possible in execution of a decree for ejectment passed by a competent civil court

anchor.surface_text: That sub-section provides that notenant shall be ejected by his landlord from the land of his tenancy except in execution of a decree for ejectment passed by a competent civil court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual reading of s.5(2) preserves execution of court decrees

holdings.text: s.5(1) non-obstante clause does not include decrees for ejectment already obtained

anchor.surface_text: It begins by stating notwithstanding anything in any contract or in any law for the time being in force but it does not include decrees for ejectment already obtained, in the non-obstante clause. Such decrees could have easily been named

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of mention of existing decrees in non-obstante clause despite ease of inclusion indicates intentional exclusion

holdings.text: s.5(1)(b) is intended to operate on rights of the landlord which are being enforced by a suit but not on rights already enforced and determined in execution

anchor.surface_text: All this seems to suggest that s. 5 1 b is intended to operate on rights of the landlord which are being enforced by a suit but not on rights already enforced and determined.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.6 specifies suits for compensation assessment, implying s.5(1)(b) suit context not execution

holdings.text: s.5(1)(a) is constructed on very similar lines to s.5(1)(b) and does not admit a different approach; contemplates a suit and not execution proceedings

anchor.surface_text: Part a of s. 5 1 is constructed on very similar lines and does not admit a different approach. ... the clause must again contemplate a suit and not execution proceedings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Structural and linguistic similarity between cls (a) and (b); operates on landlord rights enforced by suit

holdings.text: Departure from prior Assam Acts that explicitly included execution proceedings is deliberate

anchor.surface_text: These enactments, which are quite explicit, show that where the Assam Legislature wished it included execution proceedings within the protection. Being aware that if execution proceedings are to be included they need to be mentioned and having at hand the former sections as models, the departure appears to be deliberate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature had models in repealed 1947 Act s.14 and 1946/1949 Rent Control Acts s.6(1) explicitly covering executions; omission intentional

holdings.text: The decision under appeal was right

anchor.surface_text: The decision under appeal was, therefore, right.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirmation after full analysis upholding lower court's rejection of s.5 applicability to execution

anchor.surface_text: Suresh Chandra v. Ashutosh Dutta 1  expressed the same conclusion but on a slightly different reasoning. The conclusion is further strengthened when one reads the cognate sections of the earlier Assam Acts passed by the same Legislature. Section 14 of the Sylhet Non-Agricultural Urban Areas Tenancy Act, 1947 (Assam Act 10 of 1947) now repealed by the Act we are considering, provided in clear terms that proceedings in execution were included.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 14, the Sylhet Non-Agricultural Urban Areas Tenancy Act, 1917, (Assam Act 10 of 1947) was repealed. The only question in this appeal is whether s. 5 (1) (a) of the Act, which we have reproduced above, applies to execution cases in respect of decrees for ejectment granted before the coming into force of the Tenancy Act.
The decision under appeal was, therefore, right.
